BlackRock Is Likely to Lead Banks’ Safety Net FundPublished: November 21, 2007BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, a person briefed on the situation said late yesterday. A custodian for the fund could also be named shortly, according to people with knowledge of the matter, and one leading contender is Bank of New York Mellon. No official announcements have been made on either position. But with plans under way to begin raising more than $60 billion for the fund as early as next week, there is a heightened sense of urgency to fill both roles. The countrys three biggest banks  Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase  settled on the structure of the proposed fund about a week ago, after two months of complicated negotiations against the backdrop of deteriorating economic conditions. Banks and government officials are hoping that the backup fund will allow the financial instruments known as structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, to sell in an orderly fashion the more than $250 billion in assets they hold and avoid severe disruption to the already jittery credit markets. If BlackRock is appointed manager, as expected, it will be responsible for managing the securities sold into the funds portfolio, deciding whether to sell an asset at a particular price or hold it to maturity. It is not clear whether BlackRock will determine the prices or if they will be set by an outside party. The firm, which is known for its keen attention to risk, would lend both credibility and capital markets expertise to a proposal that has been shaky from the start. Recently, the firms profile has been raised with the ascension of Laurence D. Fink, its founder and chief executive, who was on the short list for the top job at Merrill Lynch and is still considered a potential candidate to run Citigroup. But BlackRock has kept its head down amid the turbulent markets. The firm recently indicated it had less than 1 percent of its cash assets invested in SIV-related debt. And it has largely steered clear of the subprime mortgage investments that have gone bad, spreading distress throughout the financial industry. BlackRock was chosen over at least two other investment management firms for the right to handle the assets of the backup fund, according to people briefed on the matter, even though Mr. Fink had previously been reserved about BlackRocks participation in the fund. A lot of the people who need to participate have needy issues and as a competitor you would like to shine a little better relative to your needy competitors, Mr. Fink said when he was questioned about selling assets into the fund while on a recent conference call announcing third-quarter earnings. He added, however, that on the other hand, youve got to have the bigger picture, making sure, if this works, it helps stabilize our markets, it helps stabilize issues surrounding our clients. Brian Beades, a BlackRock spokesman, declined to comment. The bank chosen for the custodian assignment would oversee the financial record-keeping and other back-office operations for the new fund. It would be a prominent and potentially lucrative task for Bank of New York Mellon, which has largely shunned the spotlight despite its legacy as Americas oldest bank, founded 223 years ago by Alexander Hamilton. Kevin Heine, a spokesman for the bank, declined to comment. It typically takes six months to a year for a bank to set up an ordinary structured investment vehicle, but the so-called super-SIV, though far larger and more complex, was put together by the three banks in a matter of weeks with the encouragement of the Treasury Department. How much effect it will have is unclear; many investors and analysts are skeptical that it will do much to help. Debt market conditions have rapidly deteriorated in the last few weeks as investor appetites for pools of assets  from mortgages to auto and, more recently, credit card loans  have all but dried up. And virtually all SIVs are trying to sell the securities they hold, doubting that the proposed backup fund will work. The funds organizers hope that it will buy enough time for asset prices to recover, although most market analysts say that is improbable. It may, however, discourage SIVs from dumping their holdings all at once, a move that could cause securities prices to collapse. That would force banks to take even bigger write-offs and could also put pressure on money market funds, whose exposure to SIV-issued commercial paper could put them in jeopardy. Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase are each expected to put up $5 billion to $10 billion for the fund. The remaining $60 billion or so is expected to be raised from dozens of financial institutions, including several outside the United States. Bank of America and JPMorgan will lead the fund-raising effort, while Citigroup takes a back seat. People involved with the plan said that Citigroup lacked credibility to sell the plan to investors, because it could disproportionately benefit if the plan provided relief to the seven troubled SIVs it operates. Bank of New York and Mellon Will MergePublished: December 5, 2006Bank of New York and Mellon Financial of Pittsburgh have agreed to merge in a $16.5 billion deal that will create a securities-processing powerhouse in a little-noticed corner of the financial world. Skip to next paragraph Related More From DealBook The deal, which was announced yesterday, would create the largest custodian in the financial services industry, keeping track of more than $16.6 trillion worth of assets for huge endowments, mutual funds and pension plans for whom it acts as a corporate trustee. The merged bank will also have an expanded international presence, as Mellons $1 trillion global asset management business will vault it into the industrys top 10. The combined company will be called the Bank of New York Mellon Corporation  a mouthful that links a New York bank founded by Alexander Hamilton in 1784 with a family that helped finance Pittsburghs transformation into a steel-making center. The bank will be based in New York. The deal may usher in a new wave of consolidation in a fragmented securities-processing industry. A relatively mundane business, the back-office recordkeeping of the securities positions of large institutional investors can be enormously profitable, but it is increasingly a commodity business dependent on scale. While it is unlikely that other leading institutions, like J. P. Morgan, State Street and Northern Trust, will merge with each other, they or some European banks could snap up smaller custody businesses. We viewed this strategically, said Robert P. Kelly, chief executive of Mellon, who will head the successor bank. We need to grow faster and generate the excess capital to win the arms race over the next decade. The deal helped buoy stocks yesterday, with both companies rising sharply and a rally in financial stocks. Bank of New York shares soared 12 percent, to $39.75. Mellon Financial rose 6.8 percent, to $42.78. For both institutions, the deal also represents a sort of reversal of fortune. Eight years ago, the Bank of New York tried to take over Mellon with an unsolicited offer that was quickly rebuffed. Yesterday, Mellon was in the drivers seat, providing the chief executive for the new bank. The board, though, will be controlled by Bank of New York. Under the deal, Bank of New York shareholders are receiving a 6.7 percent premium, while Mellon shareholders are essentially getting none. Mellon shareholders will receive one share in the combined company for each of their current shares; Bank of New York owners will get 0.943 share for each of theirs. Although the deal is being represented as a merger of equals, Bank of New Yorks current holders will control roughly 63 percent of the new company; Mellon holders will own about 37 percent. For Bank of New York, the deal is the latest step along a strategic path to bolster its position as leader in securities services industry and spur its growth. Earlier this year, Bank of New York shed most of its struggling retail banking business by swapping many branches for J. P. Morgan Chases corporate trust unit, a move that doubled the size of its debt-issuance recordkeeping business. With Mellon, the bank will now leap-frog Morgan as the biggest player in the custody business. It will also get Mellons asset management, a faster-growing business that may increase its stock multiple. And with at least $700 million projected annually in cost savings over the next three years, executives hope that money can be plowed back into their existing businesses to propel growth. About 3,900 workers, or a little less than 10 percent of the combined companys 40,000 employees, are expected to lose their jobs over the next three years. While the companies said they had not yet determined specific businesses or locations, the areas with the biggest overlap include asset servicing, technology and corporate staff members. The deal also engineers a smooth succession for Thomas A. Renyi, Bank of New Yorks 60-year-old chairman and chief executive, who will oversee the transition but will step aside 18 months after the Mellon transaction is complete. Mr. Kelly, 52, who took over as Mellons chairman and chief less than a year ago, will become the new companys chief executive and is expected to take over Mr. Renyis chairman role. Neither top executive will benefit from a change-in-control payout, the companies said. Coming Soon, a Backup Bank for the Treasury MarketPublished: February 28, 2006A bank created to provide emergency backup for the Treasury market will be ready to operate in the next 18 months, a bond industry group is set to announce today. The so-called NewBank exists largely on paper, but like a superhero on standby, it can spring into action to stabilize the government securities market if a legal or financial disaster strikes. The bank is a result of a five-year effort by government and banking officials to draw up plans in the unlikely event that either J. P. Morgan Chase or the Bank of New York, the only existing clearing banks in the Treasury market, are suddenly unable to operate. The two clearing banks play an obscure but crucial role in the government securities market, processing more than $1.9 trillion of very short-term trades each day between investors who want small but safe returns and dealers who want to finance securities positions. The industry's dependence on just two big institutions has long concerned the Federal Reserve, which fears the fallout of a potential trading disruption. "All of a sudden half of the securities would not be able to clear their overnight positions," said Donald H. Layton, the former vice chairman of J. P. Morgan Chase who will lead the NewBank effort. "This is a very low likelihood event but it is highly disruptive if it occurs." The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, underscored just how vulnerable the clearing system was: Bank of New York's trade-processing operations were troubled for days, causing problems across the banking system that took months to correct. Shortly after, the Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission began raising concerns about what would happen if a clearing bank's activities were severely disrupted again. Both J. P. Morgan and Bank of New York built backup facilities outside the New York metropolitan area to stay ahead of federal regulators and make sure their clearing operations could never be physically shut down. J. P. Morgan has upgraded an existing operation in Dallas; Bank of New York now has a clearing center in Florida. But in a May 2002 report, the regulators also expressed fear that sudden and unforeseen legal problems or a credit downgrade would cause either bank to abandon the clearing business. Their proposal called for a quasi-public entity that could perform emergency clearing functions for the entire Treasury market. The government-led idea drew a cool reception from the banks. In response, a working group of banking executives and government officials was formed by the Federal Reserve to examine other ways to address the problem. Their solution, a privately organized "standby bank," emerged in 2004. This dormant bank would leap into action only if a credit or legal crisis caused investors and dealers to withdraw their business from either of the two existing banks and if no other qualified buyer, like Bank of America or Citigroup, stepped forward to buy the clearing operations. Regulators released formal plans for the NewBank in December. The Bond Market Association, an industry group, is expected to announce today that it will take responsibility for enacting them over the next 12 to 18 months. The NewBank will have no physical location and no full-time employees. It will be funded with roughly $500 million from 24 banking industry shareholders so that, if needed, it could immediately have money available to begin clearing trades. It will be set up as a limited-purpose trust company under the New York state banking laws and will also be regulated by the Federal Reserve. In a crisis, however, the NewBank would take over the legal position of the existing clearing bank and replace its top officers with a small group of designated executives from other institutions. The NewBank would then take over the troubled bank's existing operations to process the trades. More Articles in Business >

Bank Settles U.S. Inquiry Into Money LaunderingPublished: November 9, 2005Federal prosecutors said yesterday that the Bank of New York agreed to pay $38 million in penalties and victim compensation in a deal stemming from a six-year investigation of fraud and money laundering involving suspect Russian and American bank accounts and other fraudulent transactions. Prosecutors said the bank, one of the nation's oldest, did not adequately monitor and report suspect accounts at the bank. The bank agreed to make what prosecutors described as "sweeping internal reforms to ensure compliance with its antifraud and money laundering obligations." Authorities said that the bank has "accepted responsibility for its criminal conduct" and that it will not be prosecuted as long as it complies with the terms of the deal for three years. Bank of New York also agreed to allow an independent examiner to monitor its operations. The investigation, which began in 1998 and ended last year, first became publicly known in the summer of 1999 when Russia's pell-mell rush to privatize formerly state-owned assets resulted in widespread criticism of insider deals and possible corruption among Russia's business elite and officials of the Kremlin. The fine, which is among the largest ever assessed against an American bank for money laundering violations, consisted of $14 million for failing to supervise suspect Russian accounts and $24 million for a separate series of fraudulent activities involving a branch on Long Island. Riggs Bank, a subsidiary of the Riggs National Corporation, paid $41 million in federal penalties this year and last to settle a high-profile investigation of money laundering problems at that institution. Prosecutors with the United States attorneys' offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn noted that the money laundering scheme at the Bank of New York involved unlicensed transmissions of about $7 billion that originated in Russia, passed through American accounts, and then moved into other accounts worldwide. Authorities said that at least nine individuals, including a former Bank of New York vice president, had been convicted for their roles in the two cases. The Bank of New York acknowledged in the settlement that it had failed to adequately police and intentionally failed to report suspect accounts at the bank. Moreover, according to the settlement, the bank's general counsel, managing counsel, and other senior executives repeatedly ignored requirements to report illicit transactions until authorities began arresting suspects in its investigations. The agreement also said that the Bank of New York subsequently provided incomplete reports about suspect activities and failed to report separate transactions that resulted in the defrauding of other banks - even though the Bank of New York had already reached an agreement with regulators to overhaul its troubled monitoring operations. "We are satisfied that reaching this agreement is in the best interest of our company and all of our constituents," the bank's chief executive, Thomas A. Renyi, wrote in a statement. "We are taking the right steps in today's environment to ensure sound business practices." Two Russian émigrés - Lucy Edwards, a former vice president at the bank, and her husband, Peter Berlin - originally opened the suspect accounts at the bank in 1996. The couple pleaded guilty to fraud charges in early 2000, conceding that they helped two Moscow banks conduct illegal operations through Bank of New York accounts. Prosecutors declined to describe the plea agreement but a person briefed on the investigation said that Ms. Edwards and her husband were among those convicted in the scheme. The couple could not be reached for comment and T. Barry Kingham, a New York lawyer representing them when they first pleaded guilty to fraud charges, did not return repeated telephone calls seeking comment. In 1999, the Bank of New York suspended Natasha Gurfinkel Kagalovsky, a senior executive who oversaw Ms. Edwards. Federal investigators were exploring Ms. Kagalovsky's possible role in the money laundering scheme at the time and she subsequently resigned from the bank and moved to London. She has never been charged with wrongdoing in connection with the investigation. Her New York lawyer, Stanley S. Arkin, said yesterday that his client never violated any laws. Ms. Kagalovsky's husband, Konstantin Kagalovsky, served in senior government and corporate posts in Russia. He once worked for two large companies, Menatep and Yukos, which the Russian billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky formerly controlled. Mr. Khodorkovsky, once one of Russia's most prominent and powerful figures, was convicted in Moscow in May on fraud and tax evasion charges in a highly disputed case pitting him against the Kremlin. A Farsighted New Fortress Mentality on Wall St.Published: September 10, 2004n May, senior executives from Wall Street's top investment banks gathered at a conference center with a cadre of federal and local law enforcement authorities. Their task for the day was to simulate, down to the last detail, the aftermath of an explosion of a bomb in Midtown followed by others in Lower Manhattan. Advertisement Their scripts, distributed to them that day, read like a Hollywood screenplay: electricity was out, telephone lines had been severed, employees were evacuating buildings and the markets were down - what do you do? The searing events of Sept. 11, 2001, when 1,400 employees of securities firms were killed, prompted some changes in and around Wall Street that are easy to see. Morgan Stanley, for instance, which lost 1.2 million square feet in the south tower of the World Trade Center, is now moving employees to a new corporate installation in Westchester with the capacity to house 3,000 people. Lehman Brothers, whose headquarters in the World Financial Center was destroyed during the attacks, is comfortably ensconced in a new office building in Midtown. But the more profound effects are less evident - like war games played by managing directors of Wall Street firms. In the wake of the loss of 32,000 financial jobs in New York State of the 211,000 before the attacks and the billions of dollars spent since on security, business continuity and disaster-recovery planning, there is a prevailing sense of wariness, both with regard to the uncertain security environment and the future direction of the markets. "People are cautious and 9/11 did not pass unnoticed," said Roy Smith, a former Goldman, Sachs partner and a professor of finance at New York University. "We have had a bubble, and there is political uncertainty. Yes, firms have let a lot of people go, but firms are adaptive and have made money other ways, such as by trading." To be sure, many of the lost jobs have resulted from trends that predate Sept. 11, 2001, like industry consolidation, more automated trading, weak equity markets and, most significantly, the migration of jobs to other places. But economists note that the attacks have hastened these trends, especially with regard to firms moving their operations. "9/11 has accelerated and expanded the need for geographic dispersion for Wall Street firms," said Frank Fernandez, chief economist for the Securities Industry Association. "The result is job losses for New York City." Not all firms have moved away. Merrill Lynch, which was forced to evacuate one of its buildings at the World Financial Center, has moved back into the building. And Goldman, Sachs, long an anchor in Lower Manhattan, is expected to start construction this year on a global headquarters in Battery Park, with its completion planned in 2008. Wall Street firms are still making billions in profits, thanks mainly to the bull market in bonds that was further spurred by the Federal Reserve's reduction of interest rates right after the attacks. But as the third anniversary of Sept. 11 approaches, an air of extreme caution pervades Wall Street - symbolized best, perhaps, by the phalanx of machine-gun toting police officers that stand guard at the New York Stock Exchange. Indeed, of all the institutions on Wall Street, the exchange - which was forced to close for four business days after the attacks and was said in August by the Bush administration to be a target of a terrorist threat - has enacted the most significant and far-reaching security and contingency plans. Since the attacks in 2001, it has spent more than $100 million to prevent or recover from a market interruption, with a contingency trading floor, capable of trading all exchange-listed stocks immediately, as the centerpiece. The exchange has also put in place a new communications system linking its data centers to its member firms through a secure network that skirts traditional phone lines. Nasdaq, the stock exchange's electronic competitor, was affected less by the attacks - it says it could have started trading on Sept. 11 - because its main trading facilities are in Connecticut, with a backup installation in Maryland. Still, it now has a contingency program that would enable it to trade all New York Stock Exchange stocks in the event of a major disruption. Wall Street firms have also upgraded their backup trading facilities, making sure they are a significant distance from their headquarters. Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch have backup operations in New Jersey, while Morgan Stanley has its new building in Westchester, which will house the retail brokerage division, to use in an emergency. The increase in spending on security, business continuity and disaster recovery has been striking. This year, analysts at the Tower Group, a consulting firm, estimate that Wall Street firms will spend $3.8 billion - up from $1.8 billion in 2001 - for contingency planning and security measures, with more than 60 percent of that dedicated to information technology and the rest going toward new building and the hiring of personnel. Spending is expected to level off in the coming years, analysts say. As for the exercises in May, they were successful, allowing the 13 broker-dealers that took part to test employee evacuation strategies and the activation of their backup sites as well as their ability to prepare for a market opening the next day. "It was intended to be as real as it could be," said Howard Sprow, the Securities Industry Association's director of business continuity planning. While Wall Street's cautious mood can, in some ways, be attributed to security concerns that linger three years later, it is also true that the wave of accounting scandals and the explosion of regulatory investigations into research and mutual fund trading abuses since the attacks have left deep marks. And while 4,000 jobs were added this summer, economists do not expect job growth on the Street to continue, especially in light of the wan markets and the strides that firms are taking to automate their trading desks, making them less dependent on labor. "Yes, you had a geopolitical event," said David Trone, a securities analyst at Fox-Pitt, Kelton, "but you also have a weak economy, automated trading in equities, regulatory issues and accounting fraud. They all hit at the same time and have changed the business in a permanent way."

U.S. Auditing Oversight Board Begins Policing Role by Settling on ProcedurePublished: October 08, 2003After a rocky start, the government's accounting oversight board is getting down to the business of policing the nation's most important accounting firms.In a flurry of major personnel announcements and votes on new rules on Tuesday, the board indicated that it would be ready early next year to begin intensively inspecting many of the auditors of publicly traded companies -- the first time accountants will face systematic examination by a government entity. McDonough, the board has also waded into a continuing controversy. The requirement, in general terms, was set by Congress, but the board's specific proposal cannot go into effect without the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which reviews its major rules and enforcement actions.The requirement followed failures of internal controls at companies including WorldCom, Xerox, Rite Aid and Cendant.The accounting board also announced that Esslie W. Robberies Of Banks RisingPublished: May 25, 2003THE series of bank robberies continued last week in Westchester.Last Wednesday at 11:15 a.m., a woman demanded money at the Bank of New York branch in the Shrub Oak Shopping Center in Yorktown, indicating she had a gun, according to the Yorktown police. One Woman Tied to Spree Of Robberies In Two StatesPublished: May 23, 2003In her jaunty baseball cap and yellow rain slicker, the middle-aged woman with the glasses and the long blonde hair might be taken for a soccer mom. Her runabout is a red compact, maybe a Mitsubishi, and she zips from town to town, and bank to bank, like a harried suburbanite juggling too many tasks.Yesterday, she made the rounds of Fairfield County in western Connecticut, stopping at a First Union Bank and a Fleet branch in Danbury, a Peoples Bank in Newtown and a Union Savings in Brookfield. Nobody was hurt, and the losses were being added up last night.By late afternoon, the state and local police in two states and in a half-dozen jurisdictions were still trying to piece together the details of what appeared to be a one-woman interstate robbery spree in the rolling green hills of Westchester and Fairfield Counties.''It's very unusual,'' said Sgt. Paul Vance, a spokesman for the Connecticut State Police. ''It's particularly unusual because of the information given out after the first one. Police were in the area, and were kind of looking around for anything after that.''It may not have been Dragnet, but William O'Shaughnessy, the chairman of Whitney Radio, said he saw a lot of patrol activity yesterday afternoon as he drove on Interstate 84 to his home in Litchfield, Conn., especially in the triangle of Danbury, Newtown and Brookfield.''I saw a trooper go blasting off at the Brookfield exit,'' he said. ''Wow! This isn't supposed to happen in the Litchfield Hills. But there are a lot of weekenders up here, and it's a little unsettling in this bucolic setting.'' Yesterday's crime wave began at 11:32 a.m. at the People's Bank branch in the Newtown Shopping Center. The robber's description was similar: a woman in her 40's, slender, light brown or blonde hair, a baseball cap, a light jacket.On Wednesday, the police in Yorktown said a woman with long blonde hair robbed the Bank of New York at the Shrub Oak shopping center at 11:15 a.m., escaping with $3,100. A few hours later, at 2:40 p.m., a woman with long blonde hair robbed the HSBC branch in Scarsdale, according to the police. She was slender and wore a yellow rain slicker, witnesses said.

Morgan almost two years ago was supposed to be that consumers in New York City would have little room for choice, industry experts and commentators said.After all, consolidation over several decades had transformed New York from a city with several dozen big banks to a place with only three major choices: Chase, Citibank and the Bank of New York.But, in fact, choice for banking customers has expanded, with nearly a dozen smaller banks seizing on perceived public discontent with the existing options and services.Some banks from outside New York, like Commerce Bank, have moved in. Others, like HSBC, which took over Republic New York, have increased their presence through mergers. And several smaller banks, like Independence Community Bank, have opened shop where Chase, Citibank and the Bank of New York have closed branches.The upstarts and newcomers are making a play for customers like Irving Singer, a Brooklyn Heights lawyer who transferred his business and personal accounts recently to Signature Bank, which Israel's largest bank, Bank Hapoalim, started 14 months ago. Signature, based in Manhattan, now has nine branches.''I have left a whole surge of banks,'' Mr. Singer said. ''The banks are too big, their service is poor, and I want to come in and get a place with personal service, where the bank manager knows my name.''Industry experts like Bruce Harting, a banking analyst at Lehman Brothers, say that consolidation -- which saves money by closing branches and sharing costs on personnel and information technology -- has had an unintended negative impact on customer service.''New Yorkers are among the most critical people in the country and at the same time this is also one of the most lucrative markets in the country,'' Mr. Harting said. ''As big as the city is, people remember their hometown banks, whether they are in Flatbush or Astoria or Greenpoint or Flushing.''Washington Mutual, which bought Dime Savings Bank in 2001, has added a store selling piggy banks, concierges, baby changing stations and roaming tellers in order to lure customers from the big banks. Based in Seattle, Washington Mutual now has 123 branches in the New York region.

50 Held in European Offshoot of Bank of New York InvestigationPublished: June 13, 2002As a tangential part of a money laundering investigation of the Bank of New York, police officials in several European countries this week detained more than 50 people suspected of involvement in a network that funneled millions of dollars from Russia through Western banks and companies.Orders were issued to freeze roughly 300 bank accounts in Europe and North America.The raids appeared to confirm concerns in several West European countries that large-scale laundering of money obtained illegally in Russia continues through seemingly legitimate businesses.Italian investigators said tonight that the arrests grew out of a little-noticed investigation into Russian organized-crime activity in an area of northeastern Italy near the seaside resort at Rimini.Russian business people became particularly active there after the Soviet collapse, buying consumer goods like clothing and shoes for the Russian market.Officials said some of the money had been funneled through accounts of the Benex Corporation and related accounts at the Bank of New York. Benex and the bank were at the center of a federal money laundering investigation in the United States in the 1990's.The investigators said that by examining bank and commercial records they were able to uncover a criminal network of mainly Russian and Italian business people. Of those detained, about 20 are being held in Italy, 12 in France and Monte Carlo, and the remainder in several other European countries and Canada. About half are Russian.They said the authorities had confiscated commercial records that could cast further light on the network and lead to more arrests.The investigators said much of the activity appeared to focus on a Rimini marketing company called Prima, controlled by Oleg Berezovsky, a 36-year-old Ã©migrÃ©. It was unclear, they said, whether Mr. Berezovsky was related to Boris Berezovsky, a high-profile Russian businessman often suspected of organized crime links. Oleg Berezovsky's brother Igor, owner of a Paris-based trading company, Kama Trade, was detained by the French police in the western French city of Rennes. The arrests were made Monday and Tuesday.The investigators said another Russian detained in France, Andreas Marissov, 38, an associate of the Berezovskys, is suspected of supplying funds and other support to rebel groups in Chechnya.The investigators also cited telephone intercepts and commercial records as evidence linking suspect West European businesses with money from criminal activity in Russia. The operation, the investigators said, may have laundered billions of dollars, but they did not specify exact amounts. Prostitution, drug sales, tax evasion and protection rackets were some of the sources of the funds in Russia, they said.Vladimir Vassarenko, a 34-year-old Russian, was a significant figure in the early stages of the investigation, they said. Mr. Vassarenko had established himself in the early 1990's in Rimini, where he organized shopping tours for Russian businessmen intent on buying Italian-made consumer goods for resale in Russia.With a business associate, Simon Bakhchinyan, Mr. Vassarenko is suspected of having broadened his activities to include smuggling artworks and illegal immigrants, including young East European women going to work in the West as prostitutes.

How Trail of Big Currency Losses Remained Uncovered for 5 YearsPublished: March 05, 2002Things were getting hot last year for John M. Rusnak, a currency trader at a Baltimore bank, which now says that he hid $691 million in losses over five years.He was not sleeping well, according to someone who knows him, and he needed cash to conceal his growing losses. He had managed to sweep $211 million of losses under the rug in 2000, according to the bank, on top of $90 million in losses the three previous years.So Mr. Rusnak dug deep into his bag of tricks and struck separate deals with four banks that generated a total of more than $200 million in cash, according to a person involved in the investigation and an executive at one of the banks.These deals were technically options trades, but they were effectively loans to Mr. Rusnak and his bank, Allfirst Financial, from Citibank, Bank of America,, Deutsche Bank and Bank of New York, say foreign exchange executives, including someone from a bank that made one of the deals. The trades enabled Mr. Rusnak to avoid attracting too much attention at Allfirst for one more year -- the last.Mr. Rusnak had already taken steps to cover his tracks with fictitious trades that the counterparties were unaware of. The prices on these fake trades were far out of the trading ranges at the time, and the firms on the other side of the apparent trades faced big losses. The terms might have raised eyebrows at some banks but apparently did not set off alarms at Allfirst, a unit of Allied Irish Banks of Dublin. In addition, the Singapore telephone number provided for confirming one trade was false. Though it was supposed to be the back office of Bank of America, the number was for a Singapore law office, according to a foreign exchange executive who has seen the fake confirmation.The four big option trades and the fake trades do not mean that there was outside collusion, though the four option trades might have been spotted by those outside the bank dealing with Mr. Rusnak. But in the dwindling world of currency trading, Mr. Rusnak was an important customer who was courted by the banks for his business. Although employed by a regional bank, he was a mover and shaker in the foreign exchange market, making deals of up to $150 million, traders said.While outsiders may have had reasons not to look too hard at a profitable client, inside Allfirst, internal controls apparently failed, as Mr. Rusnak's cover-up was so successful that under him the bank's foreign exchange revenue quintupled over five years.

Bank of New York Suit RevivedPublished: January 15, 2002A federal appeals court revived a lawsuit accusing executives of the Bank of New York Company of looting assets from Inkombank, a Russian bank that is now defunct.The suit by Inkombank depositors claims that bank executives, Russian mobsters and a few Bank of New York employees systematically transferred money through the New York-based bank and caused the Russian bank to fail.Reversing a lower court decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that the depositors had made sufficient factual claims to support a civil racketeering case.Allegations ''that senior B.N.Y. officials associated with certain senior Inkombank officials, forming an enterprise to loot Inkombank,'' were adequate to support the suit, the court said.Judge Lewis Kaplan of United States District Court dismissed the case last year, saying it should be heard in Russia. The appeals court did not address that point, but it did order Judge Kaplan to rule on another legal issue raised by the bank.The lawsuit stemmed from revelations in 1999 that a former Bank of New York executive, Lucy Edwards, and her husband, Peter Berlin, used an illegal wire-transfer operation to move billions of dollars through three accounts at the bank. Both have pleaded guilty.

INVESTING WITH/John C. Lui; BNY Hamilton Small Cap Growth FundPublished: October 21, 2001WHILE the stock market remains unsettled in the aftermath of Sept. 11, John C. Lui, who runs the $325 million BNY Hamilton Small Cap Growth fund, sees slow but steady growth ahead. ''With the Federal Reserve and the government using monetary and fiscal policy to stimulate the economy, you have to look past the negative profit projections for 2001,'' Mr. Lui said from his office in Lower Manhattan, next to the New York Stock Exchange. He expects that declines in consumer confidence will hurt the economy in the short term, he said, but that shoppers will eventually resume spending. ''Their largest asset is their home, which hasn't dropped as much as stock prices, and they have a high propensity to spend,'' he said of consumers. Over a three- to five-year corporate profit cycle, Mr. Lui said he expects a 7 percent earnings growth rate, on average, for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The fund returned 25 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 9.6 percent for its midcap growth group and 1.5 percent for the S.& P. 500, according to Morningstar Inc. It lost 25.5 percent in the last 12 months, versus a 36.1 percent loss for its group and a 19.4 drop in the S.& P. The fund, like some others with a small-cap focus, has been classified as a midcap fund by Morningstar because the average capitalization of the portfolio companies over three years exceeds Morningstar's cutoff. Mr. Lui, 44, is vice president for institutional equity management at the Bank of New York, the fund's adviser. Institutional shares require a $100,000 investment minimum, while the minimum for individuals is $2,000. To pick the fund's stocks, he screens approximately 7,000 United States companies with market capitalizations of $100 million to $2 billion. He looks for businesses in which earnings growth over the next two to three years may be underestimated by Wall Street and will exceed that of the S.& P. 500. About 150 companies meet his tests. To whittle the list -- the fund now has about 100 stocks -- he further reviews the earnings projections. ''You kick the tires,'' Mr. Lui said. ''You say: 'These are crystal-ball projections. Do these estimates make sense?' '' He receives help from two analysts of small-cap stocks but also works with seven industry analysts who focus on bigger stocks. ''Our companies sell to their companies,'' he explained, ''so we get a lot of useful information from them.'' To find growth companies, he says he looks for businesses with dominant market positions and proprietary products or services. ''We ask ourselves: 'What is the advantage of the widget that this company makes? What kind of growth rate can we expect? How long can the growth rate be sustained?' '' He also wants companies to have experienced management, preferably compensated with stock and able to communicate well with analysts, to prevent unrealistically high earnings estimates. ''With many small companies, the founders work from their garage and employ family members,'' he said. ''They think the initial offering is the end of the story. But you need Wall Street money to plan for widget No. 2.'' IN financial services, Mr. Lui said, ''we've seen niche companies that have developed a growth model.'' One of them, he said, is UCBH Holdings of San Francisco, owner of United Commercial Bank. The company focuses on serving Chinese-American customers by hiring bilingual employees and offering bilingual cash machines and Internet sites. ''This community is growing explosively,'' he said, ''but the rest of the major money center banks don't know how to cater to them.'' He originally bought shares in January 2000 at $10.31; the stock now trades at $28.80. He also likes Too Inc., a retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, that focuses on girls in the 7-to-14 age group in its Limited Too stores. The company was spun off from the Limited in 1999. ''These are customers that are in between Gap Kids and Abercrombie & Fitch,'' he said. ''There's plenty of opportunity to grow and expand. It's growing faster than the average company but sells at a discount to the S.& P. 500 companies.'' Shares sell for 16 times 2002 earnings estimates, versus a multiple of 21 for the S.& P. 500, he said, because ''people think that no one will go shopping again because of the recent events.'' He bought shares in August at $24.95; they now trade at $26.12. Mr. Lui also likes Province Healthcare, a company in Brentwood, Tenn., that owns and operates acute-care hospitals, mostly outside of urban areas. Wall Street analysts say Province's earnings are likely to grow at 25 percent a year for two or three years. He bought the stock at $28.61 in August 2000; it now trades at $32.25. Bank's Net Falls; Attacks CitedPublished: October 19, 2001Bank of New York said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 33 percent, partly because the Sept. 11 attacks knocked out some of the its computer systems and forced it to shut down branches. The bank, based in New York, had to evacuate about 8,300 workers after two hijacked planes destroyed the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. The bank said it was hurt by the cost of contingency plans and restoring its settlement and automated teller machine networks. It earned $243 million, or 33 cents a share, in the third quarter, including the impact of the attacks, compared with $363 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. The attacks pushed third-quarter profit down $140 million, more than its original estimate of $125 million. Excluding a one-time charge of 19 cents a share because of the attack, Bank of New York earned $383 million, or 52 cents a share, in the quarter. Analysts had expected 51 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
